stem: The nurse is evaluating the client's arterial blood gas (ABG) results in conjunction with their clinical presentation. Based on the provided data, for each ABG result, determine the acid-base imbalance present.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00: Received report from night shift. Client, Mr. Jones, admitted yesterday for COPD exacerbation. Reports increased shortness of breath and productive cough with thick yellow sputum. Oxygen saturation 88% on 2L nasal cannula. 

07:15: Auscultated lungs. Diffuse wheezing and crackles noted bilaterally. Client using accessory muscles to breathe. Complains of feeling anxious and restless. 

07:30: Increased oxygen to 4L nasal cannula. Encouraged pursed-lip breathing. Notified respiratory therapy for evaluation. 

08:00: Respiratory therapy arrived and initiated nebulizer treatment with albuterol/ipratropium. Repeat oxygen saturation 92%. 

08:30: Client states feeling slightly better after nebulizer treatment. Still reports shortness of breath. New ABG order received and sample sent to lab.

09:00: ABG results received. Notified provider of results and awaiting further orders. Continuous monitoring of respiratory status ongoing.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Anxious, restless, diaphoretic. 
Respiratory: Increased work of breathing, using accessory muscles. Diffuse wheezing and crackles bilaterally. Productive cough with thick yellow sputum. 
Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, regular rhythm. 
Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
•	Administer oxygen to maintain SpO2 > 90%
•	Administer nebulizer treatment with albuterol/ipratropium every 4 hours as needed.
•	Monitor respiratory status continuously.
•	Obtain arterial blood gas (ABG) STAT.
•	Notify provider of significant changes in respiratory status or ABG results.

rationale.correct: The client's ABG results indicate respiratory acidosis. The pH is below the normal range (7.35-7.45), and the PaCO2 is elevated above the normal range (35-45 mmHg). The HCO3 is within normal limits (22-26 mEq/L), indicating that there is no metabolic compensation occurring at this time.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections would indicate a misunderstanding of ABG interpretation or the relationship between pH, PaCO2, and HCO3.

answerBreakdown.rationale: A pH of 7.30 is below the normal range of 7.35-7.45, indicating acidemia. This means the client's blood is more acidic than normal.
A PaCO2 of 60 mmHg is above the normal range of 35-45 mmHg, indicating hypercapnia. Elevated PaCO2 suggests inadequate alveolar ventilation, leading to the retention of carbon dioxide.

An HCO3 of 24 mEq/L is within the normal range of 22-26 mEq/L. This indicates that the metabolic component is within normal limits and is not contributing to the acid-base imbalance or compensating for it.

clinicalPearls: Always assess the client's clinical presentation in conjunction with ABG results. ABGs are only one piece of the puzzle.
In acute respiratory acidosis, the HCO3 may still be within normal limits. Compensation takes time.
COPD patients often have chronically elevated PaCO2 levels. It's important to know their baseline.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the roles of PaCO2 and HCO3 in acid-base balance. Misinterpreting the normal ranges for pH, PaCO2, and HCO3.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Memorize normal ABG values. Use a systematic approach (e.g., ROME) to interpret ABGs. Consider the clinical context.

mnemonic.title: ROME
mnemonic.expansion: Respiratory Opposite, Metabolic Equal. In respiratory imbalances, pH and PaCO2 move in opposite directions. In metabolic imbalances, pH and HCO3 move in the same direction.
